questions.text: The pH of a solution containing 5 millimole/liter of H+ ions is closest to what value?
questions.solution: • pH = negative log of [H+]

questions.text: HCO3-/H2CO3 best buffer is due to
questions.solution:
Bicarbonate/carbonic acid buffer system:

  • Most important buffer system
  • pK=6.1
  • Ratio of base to acid 20:1
  • Lungs can readily dispose or retain CO2
  • Renal tubules can increase or decrease the rate of bicarbonate reclamation.

choices.text: Amino sugar and acid are present

questions.text: All of the following are correct about a proteoglycan except:
questions.solution:
Glycosaminoglycans (GAG):

  • containing amino sugars and uronic acids
  • Are negatively charged, so hold lot of water.
  • may be attached to a protein molecule to form a proteoglycan
  • Examples:
    • hyaluronic acid
    • chondroitin sulfate
    • heparin
    • heparin sulphate
    • dermatan sulphate
    • keratin sulphate
  • Can be organized as complex structures called mucopolysaccharide (MPS) monomer or as aggrecans.
  • Aggrecans are organized around hyaluronic acid as core.
  • Hyaluronic acid is the only GAG which does not form MPS monomers

questions.text: Lactose intolerance will be least for?
questions.solution: Lactose in yogurt has mostly been digested by the Lactoacillus!

questions.text: Glucosamines used in the treatment of:
questions.solution: Glycosaminoglycans contain amino sugars (e.g. Glucosamine) and uronic acids

questions.text: 3 ATP produced in anaerobic glycolysis with which substrate?
questions.solution:
During anaerobic Glycolysis:

  • 0,1 ATP produced in RBCs, due Rapaport Leubering Shunt (0 at high altitude; 1 at sea level)
  • 2 ATP produced in most cells.
  • 3 ATP produced in muscles, when glycogen is fuel.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes catalyze the irreversible steps of glycolysis?
questions.solution:
Irreversible reactions in glycolysis catalysed by following enzymes:

  • Pyruvate Kinase (PK)
  • Phospho-Fructo Kinase-1 (PFK-1)
  • Hexokinase/Glucokinase

questions.text: Which enzyme's activity is increased in low insulin/glucagon level?
questions.solution:
Actions of insulin:

  • Increases the activity of enzymes of:
    1. Glycolysis
    2. Glycogenesis
    3. Lipogenesis
    4. HMP shunt
    5. Amino acid synthesis
    6. Cholesterol Synthesis
  • Decreases the activity of enzymes of::
    1. Glycogenolysis
    2. Lipolysis
    3. Gluconeogenesis
    4. Ketogenesis

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme dysfunction leads to lactic acidosis in thiamine deficiency?
questions.solution:
Composition of Pyruvate Dehydrogenase Complex:

  • Enzymes:
    1. Pyruvate Dehydrogenase (E1)
    2. Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase (E2)
    3. Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase
  • Co-Enzymes:
    1. TPP (Vit B1)
    2. FAD (Vit B2)
    3. NAD (Vit B3)
    4. CoASH (Vit B5)
    5. Lipoate

questions.text: Fluoroacetate inhibits which cell cycle?
questions.solution:
Inhibitors of Kreb's Cycle:

  • Flouroacetate: non competitive inhibition of aconitase
  • Arsenite: non competitive inhibition of alpha-keto glutarate dehydrogenase
  • Malonate: competitive inhibition of succinate dehydrogenase

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of anaplerotic reaction?
questions.solution: • Anaplerotic Reactions regenerate an intermediate of Kreb’s Cycle.

questions.text: Not an intermediate product of citric acid cycle is:
The enzyme common to both glycogenolysis and glycogenesis is
A male child is brought to OPD with pain in calf muscles during exercise. Child is fatigable, and has increased glycogen deposit in muscle. What is the enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
Glycogen is the main fuel for exercising muscle, whereby it is metabolized by anaerobic glycolysis
• Initial few seconds: stored ATP
• Upto 1 minute (generally 20 seconds only): conversion of stored creatine phosphate to ATP
• After 1 minute: glycogenolysis, till blood supply is sufficiently increased.

Thus, if muscle glycogen is not available due to absence of myophosphorylase (or if glycolysis cannot occur, as in GSD-VII; Tarui’s Disease), the muscular activity cannot be sustained. An attempt to continue such activity is followed by cramping pain due to non-availability of ATP, and muscle fibrils getting trapped in the locked state of contraction (and not due to formation of lactic acid, as normally occurs in fatigued muscle).

On sustained effort to continue muscular activity, after about 7-10 minutes, there is a sudden increase in the ability to continue the exercise in patients of GSD-V. This phenomenon is known as second wind effect, and is probably due to increased blood supply, and muscles switching over to alternate fuels including fatty acids and ketone bodies.

(If Muscle phosphorylase is there then it's the best answer as McArdle’s is MC GSD in adolescent age. If it is not there, PFK-1 deficiency (GSD-VII) is the answer.)

questions.text: A 10 year old boy presents to emergency with a fainting episode during playing football. Blood examination reveals hypoglycemia, raised levels of ketone bodies, lactic acid & trigylcerides. On examination, liver & kidneys were enlarged. Histopathology of liver shows excess deposits of normally formed glycogen. What is the diagnosis?

A female infant appeared normal at birth but developed signs of liver disease one month of age and muscle weakness at 3 months and severe hypoglcemia on early morning awakening. Examination revealed hepatomegaly, laboratory analysis showed ketoacidosis, pH 7.2, increased AST and ALT. Intravenous administration glucagon followed by glucose normalised blood levels, but glucose levels did not rise when glucagon was administered after overnight fasting. Glycogen store was (8%) of wet weight.With the above pictures which of the following enzyme is deficient
questions.solution:
Type IIIa Glycogen Storage Disease or Cori’s Disease or Forbes Disease:

  • Caused by a deficiency of glycogen debranching enzyme.
  • Childhood: Hepatomegaly, growth retardation, muscle weakness, fasting hypoglycemia,
  • Accumulation of characteristic branched polysaccharide (limit dextrins)

questions.text: A 15 days old child is brought to the paediatric emergency with complaints of vomiting and poor feeding. On examination, oil drop cataract is seen bilaterally. Biochemical evaluation shows the GALT enzymatic deficiency. On urine examination, what is the likely finding?
questions.solution: GALT enzyme is another name for Gal-1Phosphate Uridyl Transferase, which is deficient in Galactosemia. Galactose is elevated in blood and appears in urine; hence Benedict's test is positive.

questions.text: Exclusively breast-fed neonate presents to emergency in the 7th month of life with complaints of vomiting, lethargy and poor feeding. The resident on duty suspects inborn error of metabolism. Urine examination was negative by glucose-oxidase test, but positive in Benedict's test for reducing substance. Most likely IEM is:
questions.solution:
'Hereditary fructose intolerance (HFI) is an inborn error of fructose metabolism caused by a deficiency of the enzyme aldolase B. It is an autosomal recessive condition. Individuals affected with HFI are asymptomatic until they ingest fructose, sucrose, or sorbitol. If fructose is ingested, the enzymatic block at aldolase B causes an accumulation of fructose-1-phosphate. This accumulation has downstream effects on gluconeogenesis and regeneration of adenosine triphosphate (ATP). Symptoms of HFI include vomiting, hypoglycemia, jaundice, hemorrhage, hepatomegaly, hyperuricemia and potentially kidney failure'.

Hence, typically, a patient of hereditary fructose intolerance remains asymptomatic till the time of 'weaning'.

questions.text: After overnight fasting, levels of glucose transporters are reduced in:
A 3 year old child has hepatosplenomegaly. On examination of the bone marrow, large cells are seen with crumpled paper appearance. Which of the following must have accumulated in these cells?
questions.solution:
Gaucher's Disease:

  • Most common lysosomal storage disorder.
  • β-glucosidase, aka, glucocerebrosidase and glucosylceramidase
  • Cherry red spot, mental retardation not seen.
  • Gaucher cells with wrinkled paper appearance.
  • Acute abdominal pain & bone crises.
  • Serum levels of chitotriosidase, ACE, TRAP, & chemokine CCL18/PARC (pulmonary and activation–regulated chemokine) are very high.

questions.text: In Cerebrohepatorenal syndrome, which of the following accumulate in brain?
questions.solution: Cerebrohepatorenal syndrome is the other name for Zellweger syndrome, in which the peroxisome synthesis or enzymes therein, are deficient. Very long chain fatty acids are exclusively metabolised in the peroxisomes, unlike the SCGA, MCFA & LCFA, which are metabolised in the mitochondria. As a result, accumulation of VLCFA occurs, most prominently in the CNS.

questions.text: Find out the value of LDL, if total cholesterol level is 300 mg/dL, HDL level is 25 mg/dL and triglycerides level is 150 mg/dL?
questions.solution:
Friedwald Formula for LDL:

LDL= Total Ch – (HDL + VLDL), where VLDL= {TG/5}

questions.text: The reason for high VLDL and TG level in uncontrolled diabetes mellitus is?
questions.solution: • Insulin inhibits hormone sensitive lipase and activates lipoprotein lipase

questions.text: On laboratory investigations in a patient, LDL was highly elevated but the level of LDL receptors was normal. Which of the following is most probable cause?

Which of the following flipped pattern of LDH [flipping of LDH] is seen in myocardial infarction?
questions.solution: • Normally, LDH 2 is maximum, and it comes from RBCs. LDH 1, which is produced in heart, will be more in case of MI. Thus, the LDH 1:2 is reversed or 'flipped'!

questions.text: Substrate linking Krebs's cycle with urea cycle is:
questions.solution: • Fumarate, generated in Reaction 4, is recycled via Kreb's cycle to regenerate Aspartate, which is used in Reaction 3!

questions.text: A 4-year old boy of a first degree consanguinous couple was noted by the parents to have darkening of the urine to an almost black colour when it was left standing. He has normal siblings, and there are no other associated medical problems. Growth and development to date are normal. Which of the following enzymes is likely deficient in this patient? (NE-2020-11)
questions.solution:
Alkaptonuria:

  • Defective enzyme: Homogentisate oxidase
  • Urine becomes black on standing; parents complain of black diapers.
  • Second presentation during late 30s/early 40s with erosive arthritis, back pain/stiffness and ochronosis.

questions.text: Deficiency of which of the following amino acids can cause the condition shown in the figure:
questions.solution: • Casal Collar/Necklace is a characteristic feature of Pellagra, Vit B3 deficiency. Vit B3/Niacin is synthesized from Tryptophan.

questions.text: Which of the following urine odours is not correctly matched:

A girl with habit of eating paint peeled off from the wall presented with complaints of acute abdominal pain on and off with tingling sensation of limbs associated with weakness of the limbs. Which of the enzyme will show reduced activity in this patient?
questions.solution: • High levels of lead can affect heme metabolism by combining with SH groups in enzymes such as Ferrochelatase and ALA dehydratase (zinc containing enzyme). This affects porphyrin metabolism. Elevated levels of protoporphyrin are found in red blood cells and elevated levels of ALA and Coproporphyrin are found in urine.

questions.text: After a point mutation, glutamic acid is replaced by valine, which leads to formation of sickle cell hemoglobin. The mobility of HbS as compared with normal hemoglobin on gel electrophoresis will be?
questions.solution: • Overall charge will decrease, so movement in electric field, which depends on native charge, will also decrease

Klenow fragment is due to absence of which enzymatic activity?
questions.solution: • Klenow Fragment is DNA Polymerase 1 without the 5’-3’ exonuclease activity, which is removed by enzymatic cleavage.

questions.text: Fastest way to re-generate ATP during exercise
questions.solution:
In exercising muscle, source of energy is:

  • Initial few seconds: stored ATP
  • Upto 1 minute (generally 20 seconds only): conversion of stored creatine phosphate to ATP
  • After 1 minute: glycogenolysis, till blood supply is sufficiently increased.

questions.text: A person starts eating a dozen raw eggs daily for protein. He now develops fatigue, weakness and hypoglycemia on moderate exercise. The doctor prescribes a vitamin. Which enzyme is deficient in him?
questions.solution:
Biotin(B7/H):

  • Coenzyme of carboxylase enzymes:
    • acetyl-CoA carboxylase
    • pyruvate carboxylase
    • propionyl-CoA carboxylase
    • methylcrotonyl-CoA carboxylase
  • Plays a role in regulation of cell cycle.
  • Widely distributed in food, dietary deficiency is unknown
    • Can occur in prolonged parenetral nutrition
    • Can occur with consumption of large amounts of uncooked egg white
      • contains avidin, binds biotin, prevents absorption.

questions.text: A young man met with a motor bike accident and had injury to ileum and jejunum. Therefore, the entire ileum and partial jejunum was resected. Which of the following is the patient most likely to suffer from:
questions.solution: • Absorption of Vit B12 occurs exclusively in the ileum!!

questions.text: A 20 year old alcoholic malnourished patient presented to hospital with respiratory distress. His pulse was 112/min. Patient had edema, hypertension, and systolic murmur along the left sternal edge. Bilateral crepitations were felt in the lungs. A diagnosis of congestive high output cardiac failure was made. Which vitamin is deficient?
questions.solution:
Beri-Beri (Thiamine Deficiency)

  • Dry Berry Beri:-
    • It involves CNS in the form of parasthesia, general weakness, atrophy, foot and wrist drop.
  • Wet Berry Beri:-
    • It involves CVS in the form of palpitation, tachycardia, AR, edema, high cardiac output failure
  • Acute/Infant Berry Beri:-
    • Seen in those infants whose mothers milk is deficient in B1

questions.text: Name the phenomenon:
In the given GTT graph, graph B denotes
questions.solution:
• 0 Hour value: 120 mg/dl
  • 2 Hour value: 160 mg/dl

So, clearly this is neither Normal, nor sufficiently elevated to be categorized as overt Diabetes Mellitus. Such results are indicative of impaired glucose tolerance, which is likely to progress to DM in the near future in absence of any timely intervention like lifestyle and dietary modifications.

choices.text: Responsible for maintaining fidelity of DNA replication

questions.text: All are true regarding telomerase except:
The correct order of steps in Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is:
questions.solution:
1. Polymerase Chain Reaction:
    1. A technique used to amplify a selected segment of DNA in laboratory without using biological systems.
    2. Developed in 1983 by Kary Mullis.
    3. Useful as a precursor to several techniques, since it amplifies the quantity of available DNA by a magnitude of 6 (106 times):
      1. Southern and Northern hybridization
      2. Diagnosis of genetically inherited diseases.
      3. Diagnosis of infectious diseases (e.g. T.B.)
      4. For DNA finger printing; used in forensics and paternity claims.
      5. DNA cloning.
      6. DNA sequencing.
      7. Recombinant DNA technology
      8. Gene expression studies.
      9. Detection of malignant diseases such as leukemia and lymphomas.
    4. Substrates of a PCR reaction:
      1. Template DNA
      2. dNTPs
      3. Primers
      4. Taq polymerase
      5. Buffer
      6. Mg++
    5. Steps of traditional PCR:
      1. Denaturation: Temp range 90°-94° C, causes separation of DNA strands. (bypasses the need for helicase enzyme)
      2. Annealing: Temp range 45°-65° C, depends on the primer composition, can be roughly calculated by the formula= 2 *(A+T) + 4*(G+C)
      3. Elongation: Temp range 70°-74° C, optimum temp of Taq polymerase enzyme. (Different polymerases will have different optimum temp)
    6. Commonly used variations of PCR:
      1. Hot start PCR
      2. Multiplex PCR
      3. Reverse Transcription PCR All of these will need gel electrophoresis to verify and check the result of PCR.
      4. Real Time PCR: also known as quantitative PCR, since it is used to quantify the starting amount of DNA/RNA before the PCR reaction.
      5. Isothermal PCR: where all reactions can be carried out at the same temp; made possible by either using helicase enzyme, or Bst polymerase, which has inherent helicase action in addition to the polymerase action.

questions.text: Thermic effect of food is highest for:
questions.solution:
Thermic effect of food:

  • Carbohydrates: 5-10%
  • Fats: 10-15%
  • Proteins: 20-30%

questions.text: Hayflick limit is?
Vitamin deficient causing neonatal seizures
questions.solution:
• Pyridoxine-dependent seizure/epilepsy(PDS/PDE) is a recognized cause of intractable seizures in neonates, psychomotor developmental delay, and, sometimes, death in untreated patients
  • Folinic Acid Responsive Epilepsy
  • Biotinidase deficiency causing multiple carboxylase deficiency and presenting with seizures
  • Seizures with vitamin B12 deficiency are rare, but reported.
